critique: This document pertains to worker's compensation in the Panama Canal Zone in 1914. It amends a previous executive order to adjust the compensation paid to dependents of deceased employees. Given the historical context, the document reflects early 20th-century attitudes towards worker welfare and family support. There is no clear indication of ideological tilt, immigration policy, or impacts on civil liberties. The document does expand the power of the Governor of The Panama Canal to determine the distribution of benefits, which could be seen as expanding executive power within that specific context. There is no clear indication of federalism or social inclusion. The economic regulation is moderate, as it deals with worker's compensation.
